revised_title: Mating Structure and Sex Ratio Variation in a Natural Population of Nasonia vitripennis
tldr: This study examines the mating structure and sex ratio variation in a natural population of the parasitoid wasp Nasonia vitripennis. Researchers found that the wasps adjust their sex ratios in response to variation in foundress numbers, resulting in a female-biased population sex ratio. The observed foundress numbers per patch were variable, but most patches had one or two foundresses, confirming the prerequisites for the evolution of female-biased sex ratios in N. vitripennis.
